importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication indicates the timing of the Amazon cloud outage event and its aftermath, highlighting a real-time technological disruption that occurred in the early hours of the day.
The outage was resolved by 6 p.m. Eastern time on this date, marking the end of a widespread service disruption that began early Monday morning.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The outage began at approximately 3:11 a.m. Eastern time and was resolved by 6 p.m. Eastern time, illustrating the duration and scale of the disruption across global digital services.

keyTakeAways: Amazon Web Services (AWS) experienced a significant outage affecting its US-EAST-1 region, disrupting services like social media, gaming, food delivery, streaming, financial platforms, and education platforms such as Canvas.
The outage was caused by issues within AWS’s domain name system (DNS), which converts web addresses into IP addresses, a critical function for internet connectivity.
More than 2,500 companies reported outages, with users affected by Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, Netflix, Disney+, Signal, Coinbase, and McDonald’s app.

Educational institutions such as the University of California, Riverside, and Ohio State University experienced disruptions in online learning, with students unable to submit assignments or access course materials.
This outage underscores the vulnerability of modern digital society, which depends heavily on a few major tech companies for cloud infrastructure.

Cybersecurity experts like Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess note that while such outages are common and typically resolve within hours, they highlight the fragility of internet infrastructure when centralized on a few providers.
AWS reported that 64 internal services were impacted, and recovery was described as 'slow and bumpy,' similar to a post-power-outage scenario.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amazon Web Services (AWS) suffered a major outage beginning at 3:11 a.m. Eastern time on October 20, 2025, affecting 64 of its internal services in the US-EAST-1 region. The root cause was identified as a failure in AWS’s domain name system (DNS), which disrupted internet access for a wide range of services, including social media platforms like Snapchat and Roblox, gaming apps such as Fortnite, financial services like Robinhood and Coinbase, streaming services like Netflix and Disney+, and educational platforms such as Canvas. The outage also impacted Amazon’s own products, including Ring doorbell cameras and Alexa smart speakers. Educational institutions, including the University of California, Riverside, and Ohio State University, reported that students could not access course materials or submit assignments. Recovery was completed by 6 p.m. Eastern time, though the process was described as slow and bumpy. Experts like Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess noted that such outages are common and typically resolve within hours, and are likely due to technical issues, not cyberattacks. This incident underscores the fragility of modern internet infrastructure, which increasingly relies on a small number of companies like Amazon for critical cloud computing services.
title: Amazon Cloud Outage Exposes Internet’s Fragile Backbone
